'''Ray Wylie Hubbard''' (born November 13, 1946) is an American singer and songwriter.

== Early life ==
Hubbard was born on November 13, 1946, in [[Soper, Oklahoma]].<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/ray-wylie-hubbard-mn0000414291/biography|title=Ray Wylie Hubbard biography|last=Ankeny|first=Jason|work=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=November 3, 2015}}</ref> His family moved to [[Oak Cliff]] in southwest [[Dallas, Texas]], in 1954.  He attended [[W. H. Adamson High School]] with [[Michael Martin Murphey]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.mrt.com/entertainment/article_e6da5a56-aec1-5ad4-abbe-a29e681c7235.html | title=Ray  | work=Midland Reporter-Telegram | date=November 15, 2011 | access-date=December 1, 2014 | author=Temple, Georgia}}</ref> Hubbard graduated in 1965 and enrolled in North Texas State University (now the [[University of North Texas]]) as an English major. He spent the summers in [[Red River, New Mexico]], playing folk music in hootenannies with a trio known as Three Faces West.<ref name=tucker>{{cite web|url=https://www.dmagazine.com/publications/d-magazine/1993/march/the-second-life-of-ray-wylie-hubbard/|author=Tucker, Chris|title=THE SECOND LIFE OF RAY WYLIE HUBBARD|publisher=[[D Magazine]]|website=dmagazine.com|date=March 1993}}</ref>

== Career ==
=== 1970s ===
During his time in New Mexico, Hubbard wrote "Up Against the Wall, Redneck Mother"<ref name=tucker /> first made famous by [[Jerry Jeff Walker]]'s 1973 recording, and covered by a wide variety of other artists since.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://secondhandsongs.com/work/141406/versions|title=''Up Against the Wall Redneck Mother'' written by Ray Wylie Hubbard|website=SecondHandSongs.com|access-date=March 22, 2019}}</ref> Bolstered by the success of the song, he was signed by [[Warner Bros. Records]]. Hubbard then assembled a band of friends and locals and, in 1976, released ''Ray Wylie Hubbard and the Cowboy Twinkies.''<ref name=Christgau>{{cite web|url=https://www.robertchristgau.com/get_artist2.php?id=4801|author=Christgau, Robert|title=Ray Wylie Hubbard & the Cowboy Twinkies [extended]|website=RobertChristgau.com|access-date=March 22, 2019}}</ref> Unbeknownst to Hubbard, producer Michael Brovsky had decided to "Nashville-ize" the sound by adding overdub mixes and female backup singers to the recordings. The result was "a botched sound" that Hubbard disapproved of vehemently, but the album was released despite his attempts to block it.<ref name=tucker />

=== 1980s ===
Hubbard then recorded albums for various other labels for the next decade, but struggled with the sales of his mix of [[country music|country]], [[folk music|folk]] and [[blues]].<ref name=Jurek>{{cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Life-Well-Lived-Wylie-Hubbard-ebook/dp/B07KBC4V54|title=A Life....Well, Lived [Print Replica] Kindle Edition (2018)|publisher=Amazon Digital Services LLC|author=Ray Wylie Hubbard with Thom Jurek|date=November 7, 2018 |access-date=November 7, 2018}}</ref> The last album he recorded in the 1980s was ''Caught in the Act'' (1984) on his newly formed ''Misery Loves Company'' record label.

=== 1990s and beyond ===
[[File:Ray Wylie Hubbard.jpg|upright=0.9|thumb|Hubbard performing in 2009]]
He returned to recording in the early 1990s, and released his album ''Lost Train of Thought'' in 1992,<ref name=tucker /> followed by ''Loco Gringo's Lament'' in 1994. Eventually a steady following began to re-discover Hubbard's music and he has been recording steadily since.

He describes his 2017 album ''Tell the Devil I'm Getting There as Fast as I Can'' as rock & roll, though his style has become associated with [[outlaw country]].<ref name=Gage>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/ray-wylie-hubbard-on-new-album-i-still-enjoy-being-a-smartass-195506/|title=Ray Wylie Hubbard on New Album: 'I Still Enjoy Being a Smartass'|author=Gage, Jeff|website=RollingStone.com|date=August 22, 2017 |publisher=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=August 22, 2017}}</ref>

== Discography ==
* 1975 ''Ray Wylie Hubbard and the Cowboy Twinkies'' – [[Warner Bros. Records]]<ref name=Christgau />
* 1978 ''Off the Wall'' – Lone Star Records/Mercury/Polygram<ref>Kurt Wolff, Orla Duane – Country Music: The Rough Guide 2000- Page 359 1858285348 "During the mid-'70s he and his band recorded tor Atlantic and Warner Brothers, then Hubbard cut a solo album, OFF THE WALL, for Willie Nelson's Lone Star label"</ref>
* 1979 ''Something About the Night'' – Renegade Records
* 1984 ''Caught in the Act'' – Misery Loves Company Records
* 1992 ''Lost Train of Thought'' – Misery Loves Company/DejaDisc Records
* 1994 ''Loco Gringo's Lament'' – Misery Loves Company/DejaDisc Records
* 1997 ''Dangerous Spirits'' – [[Rounder Records|Rounder]]/Philo Records<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=2311|title=Ray Wylie Hubbard – ''Dangerous Spirits'' – 1997 (Rounder)|author=Steinberg, Brian|website=CountryStandardTime.com|publisher=[[Country Standard Time]]|date=1997}}</ref>
* 1998 ''Live at Cibolo Creek'' – Misery Loves Company Records
* 1999 ''Crusades of the Restless Knights'' – Rounder/Philo Records
* 2001 ''Eternal and Lowdown'' – Rounder/Philo Records<ref name=Wooldridge>{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=2308|title=Ray Wylie Hubbard – ''Growl'' – 2003 (Rounder)|author=Wooldridge, Robert|website=CountryStandardTime.com|publisher=[[Country Standard Time]]|date=2003}}</ref>
* 2003 ''Growl'' – Rounder/Philo Records<ref name=Wooldridge />
* 2005 ''Delirium Tremolos'' – Rounder/Philo Records
* 2006 ''Snake Farm'' – Sustain Records<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.acousticmusic.com/fame/p03929.htm|title=''Snake Farm'' : Ray Wylie Hubbard|author=Gottlieb, Bob|website=AcousticMusic.com|publisher=Peterborough Folk Music Society|date=2006}}</ref>
* 2010 ''A. Enlightenment B. Endarkenment (Hint: There is No C)'' – Bordello Records (Thirty Tigers/RED)
* 2012 ''[[The Grifter's Hymnal]]'' – Bordello Records (Thirty Tigers/RED)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://lonestarmusicmagazine.com/qa-ray-wylie-hubbard-3/|title=Q & A : RAY WYLIE HUBBARD – The Wylie Lama on life, death, damnation, Beatles, blues, and the fine art of grifting|author=Dansby, Andrew|website=LoneStarMusicMagazine.com|date=March 2012 |publisher=[[Lone Star Music]]|access-date=March 1, 2012}}</ref>
* 2015 ''The Ruffian's Misfortune'' – Bordello Records (Thirty Tigers/RED)
* 2017 ''Tell the Devil That I'm Getting There As Fast As I Can'' – Bordello Records (Thirty Tigers/RED)<ref name=Gage /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tahoeonstage.com/album-reviews/ray-wylie-hubbard/|title=Review: Ray Wylie Hubbard gives the devil run for money|website=TahoeOnstage.com|author=Clarke, Tom|access-date=September 14, 2017}}</ref>
* 2020 ''Co-Starring'' – [[Big Machine Records]]
* 2022 ''Co-Starring Too'' – [[Big Machine Records]] – Released March 18, 2022

== Books ==
* ''A Life... Well, Lived'' (biography and memoir published in 2015)<ref name=Jurek /><ref name=Gage /><ref>from an interview on [http://americanamusicshow.com/episode254 Americana Music Show #254], published July 7, 2015.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://lonestarmusicmagazine.com/book-review-ray-wylie-hubbards-a-life-well-lived/|title=BOOK REVIEW: "A LIFE … WELL, LIVED" by Ray Wylie Hubbard with Thom Jurek|author=Bloom, D.C.|website=LoneStarMusicMagazine.com|date=November 17, 2015 |publisher=[[Lone Star Music]]|access-date=November 17, 2015}}</ref>
* ''The Messenger: The Songwriting Legacy of Ray Wylie Hubbard'' by author Brian T. Atkinson was published by Texas A&M University Press in 2019. The book includes forewords by Jerry Jeff Walker and Hayes Carll.
